message.content: This question requires some basic knowledge about the classification of different types of mixtures. A true combination of mixed substances refers to a homogeneous mixture, where the different substances are evenly distributed and cannot be easily separated. Option (C), cream and coffee, is an example of a homogeneous mixture because when cream is added to coffee, they mix together to form a uniform solution. Option (A), corn with butter, is not a true combination of mixed substances because the corn and butter can be easily separated. Option (B), sand and pebbles, is an example of a heterogeneous mixture because the sand and pebbles can be visually distinguished and separated. Option (D), dirt and sand, is another example of a heterogeneous mixture because the dirt and sand can be visually distinguished and separated.

This question requires understanding of the difference between mixtures and true combinations. A true combination is when two or more substances are chemically bonded together to form a new substance with different properties. In option (C), cream and coffee combine to create a new substance, coffee with cream, in which the molecules of the cream and coffee are mixed together. Option (A) is incorrect because corn and butter only mix together but do not chemically bond. Option (B) is incorrect because sand and pebbles are simply physically mixed and can be separated. Option (D) is incorrect because dirt and sand is also a physical mixture and not a true combination.

This question requires knowledge about mixtures and the difference between true combinations and mixtures. A true combination is when two or more substances are chemically combined and cannot be easily separated. Option (A) is incorrect because corn and butter can be easily separated. Option (B) is incorrect because sand and pebbles are physically mixed and can be separated. Option (D) is incorrect because dirt and sand are also physically mixed and can be separated. Option (C) is the correct answer because cream and coffee, when mixed together, form a solution where the molecules of both substances are evenly distributed and cannot be easily separated.

This question requires an understanding of mixtures and combinations. A true combination of mixed substances occurs when the individual substances mix together completely and cannot be easily separated. Option (C), cream and coffee, is an example of this because when cream is added to coffee, it mixes completely to form a homogenous mixture. Options (A) and (D) are not true combinations because the individual substances can still be separated, such as separating the corn from the butter or the dirt from the sand. Option (B) is a mixture of two substances, but they do not mix completely and can be separated easily, so it is not a true combination.

To determine the correct answer, we need to understand what a true combination of mixed substances is. A true combination refers to when two or more substances combine to form a new substance with uniform composition.

Option (A), corn with butter, is not a true combination of mixed substances because corn and butter retain their individual characteristics even when combined.

Option (B), sand and pebbles, is not a true combination of mixed substances because sand and pebbles can be physically separated and they do not combine to form a new substance.

Option (C), cream and coffee, is a true combination of mixed substances because when cream is mixed with coffee, a homogeneous mixture called coffee with cream is formed. The cream disperses evenly throughout the coffee, resulting in a uniform composition.

Option (D), dirt and sand, is not a true combination of mixed substances because dirt and sand can be physically separated and they do not combine to form a new substance.

Therefore, the correct answer is (C) cream and coffee.

This question tests our understanding of mixtures and whether they are true combinations or not. A true combination of mixed substances refers to a homogeneous mixture where the individual substances are evenly distributed and cannot be separated by simple physical means. Option (C), cream and coffee, is an example of a true combination because when cream is added to coffee, it dissolves and forms a homogeneous mixture called a solution. Option (A), corn with butter, is not a true combination because the butter coats the corn but does not dissolve into it. Option (B), sand and pebbles, is a heterogeneous mixture because the sand and pebbles can be easily separated by physical means. Option (D), dirt and sand, is also a heterogeneous mixture because the different components of the mixture can be visually distinguished and separated.

To answer this question, we need to understand the concept of mixtures. A true combination of mixed substances refers to a homogeneous mixture, where the substances are evenly distributed and cannot be easily separated.

Option (A), corn with butter, is not a true combination of mixed substances because the corn and butter can be easily separated.

Option (B), sand and pebbles, is not a true combination of mixed substances because the sand and pebbles can be sorted and separated.

Option (C), cream and coffee, is a true combination of mixed substances. When cream is added to coffee, it dissolves and becomes uniformly distributed throughout the coffee, creating a homogeneous mixture. The cream cannot be easily separated from the coffee.

Option (D), dirt and sand, is not a true combination of mixed substances because the dirt and sand can be separated by various methods such as filtering.

Therefore, the correct answer is (C) cream and coffee.

To answer this question, we need to understand the difference between a mixture and a true combination of mixed substances. A true combination of mixed substances is a homogeneous mixture where the different components are chemically combined and cannot be easily separated.

Option (A) is incorrect because corn and butter can be easily separated and are not chemically combined. Option (B) is also incorrect because sand and pebbles are physically mixed and not chemically combined. Option (D) is incorrect for the same reason as option (B).

Option (C) is the correct answer because when cream and coffee are mixed together, they create a uniform and homogeneous solution where the molecules of coffee and cream are chemically combined. It is difficult to separate the individual components of the mixture once they are combined.
